natural problem: The sequence $a_1,$ $a_2,$ $a_3,$ $\dots$ satisfies $a_1 = 19,$ $a_9 = 99,$ and for all $n \ge 3,$ $a_n$ is the arithmetic mean of the first $n - 1$ terms.  Find $a_2.$
natural solution: For $n \ge 3,$ we have that \[a_n = \frac{a_1 + a_2 + \dots + a_{n - 1}}{n - 1},\]or \[(n - 1) a_n = a_1 + a_2 + \dots + a_{n - 1}.\]Likewise, \[n a_{n + 1} = a_1 + a_2 + \dots + a_{n - 1} + a_n.\]Subtracting these equations, we get

\[n a_{n + 1} - (n - 1) a_n = a_n,\]so $n a_{n + 1} = n a_n.$  Then $a_{n + 1} = a_n.$ This means that the terms $a_3,$ $a_4,$ $a_5,$ $\dots$ are all equal. In particular, $a_3 = 99,$ so \[\frac{19 + a_2}{2} = 99.\]We find $a_2 = \boxed{179}.$

a_0.formal problem:

fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 19"
and h1 : "a 9 = 99"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 3 \<longrightarrow> a n = (sum a {1..<n}) / (n - 1)"
shows  "a 2 = 179"

 \[n a_{n + 1} - (n - 1) a_n = a_n,\]so $n a_{n + 1} = n a_n.$  Then $a_{n + 1} = a_n.$ This means that the terms $a_3,$ $a_4,$ $a_5,$ $\dots$ are all equal. In particular, $a_3 = 99,$ so \[\frac{19 + a_2}{2} = 99.\]We find $a_2 = \boxed{179}.$
 *)
